To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Sir:
Having attended the Barnstormers'
production of Once In A Lifetime, last
Saturday night, I was favorably impressed by it, except for one thing.
This was the swearing and other loose
talk which were in some of the female
parts. In my opinion, this was rather
unattractive, and might well have
been deleted, since the producers
changed enough words to include Dean
Berry in one of the lines.
It would be interesting to know
what the reaction of the rest of the
audience was. Those students to whom
I have talked have felt the same as I
do. They agree that these expressions
were forced and unnatural. A profesional actress might have been able
to make it seem unaffected, but it did
not go over in this case. I do not wish
to imply that I think that plays should
be censored as strictly as are movies,
but I do believe that such 'things as the
aforementioned could very well be
left out in college performances of
these plays.

EDITOR

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
Sir:
Having attended the Barnstormers'
production of Once In A Lifetime, last
Saturday night, I was favorably impressed by it, except for one thing.
This was the swearing and other loose
talk which were in some of the female
parts. In my opinion, this was rather
unattractive, and might well have
been deleted, since the producers
changed enough words to include Dean
Berry in one of the lines.
It would be interesting to know
what the reaction of the rest of the
audience was. Those students to whom
I have talked have felt the same as I
do. They agree that these expressions
were forced and unnatural. A profesional actress might have been able
to make it seem unaffected, but it did
not go over in this case. I do not wish
to imply that I think that plays should
be censored as strictly as are movies,
but I do believe that such 'things as the
aforementioned could very well be
left out in college performances of
these plays.
John Harwood Stanford, Jr.

Another milestone of the broad, extensive Hopkins' intramural program
was achieved when the first half of
the basketball program reached a
successful conclusion. Since football
made its glorious exit, basketball
has been in full swing.
For the past several weeks, wellknit and organized fives have been
clashing each day at the gymnasium.
Most games have been remarkably
close and well played, and few teams
have been formidable enough to carry
off honors without competition. Thus
far, Reuben Baer and his most competent staff have performed capably
in the management of court activities.
Play Starts After Xmas
As soon as Christmas vacation is
over, the second half tilts will be
scheduled. Following precedent, teams
are divided into leagues at the end of
the campaign, the victors of each division will meet in a play-off series.
And the final winner of this tourney
will be crowned champion of the entire school.
